Clayton County Public Schools (CCPS) reminds parents, guardians and caregivers to take advantage of an assistance program that will offset additional food costs caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Pandemic-EBT (P-EBT) program is designed to reimburse families for missed free and reduced lunches from March - May 2020 due to the pandemic.

Children whose families already received food stamps received the money automatically because Georgia DFCS could automatically upload the EBT cards that the families had. However, there are a substantial number of families who still need to apply so the P-EBT cards can be sent to them.

The amount of this benefit is about $256 per child and the application process is very easy. The deadline to apply is Sept. 25! Please see the attached reminder in English and Spanish with all the information and links needed to complete an application.

The Clayton County Public Schools (CCPS) Department of School Nutrition is pleased to share information about another resource to help families in Clayton County who are experiencing food insecurities.

The Georgia Division of Family & Children Services (DFCS) is partnering with the Georgia Department of Education (GaDOE) to provide food benefits to families with children who receive free and reduced lunch. The Family First Coronavirus Response Act of 2020 allows the Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) to facilitate the distribution of Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer Program (P-EBT).

Starting in July 2020, both DFCS and DOE, under the recently approved P-EBT plan, will issue funds to eligible families to offset additional food costs caused by the pandemic. The temporary funding includes a one-time allotment of $265.50 per eligible child and is intended to prevent food insecurity for families across Georgia.

Please take time to carefully read the attached documents for more details about the P-EBT program.

Clayton County Public Schools is proud to congratulate Christian Zamora, a senior at Martha Ellen Stilwell School of the Arts, as he has been selected to receive the Count Basie-Scotty Barnhart Jazz Scholarship!

Named after world-renown Jazz Big Band Musician, Count Basie, and the current leader of the Basie Orchestra, Scotty Barnhart, this scholarship was created to help support students of Jazz music seek advanced degrees in music. This scholarship will provide $1,000 to be applied to Christian’s college tuition in the fall.

Competing against numerous students across the United States, Christian was required to submit a recorded audition on youtube playing a jazz standard, an essay, a letter of recommendation from the director of bands, and also maintain a GPA of at least a 3.0 or higher. Christian was also, the number one high school saxophonist in the state of Georgia jazz Allstate band this year.

Congratulations Christian! To view Christian’s youtube audition, please see the following video!

State Postpones May 19 Presidential Preference and General Election Primaries | May 11, 2020 Deadline to Register to Vote

With respect to the spread of COVID-19 and continued mandates related to sheltering in place and social distancing, the Georgia Department of Elections has postponed the state’s Presidential Preference Primary and the General Election Primary, which had been set for May 19, 2020. Registered voters will now be able to cast those votes on Tuesday, June 9, 2020.

The deadline to register to vote is May 11, 2020. Early and advance voting will be from May 18, 2020, to June 5, 2020, and will be held at six locations. All registered voters in Clayton County have been sent an application to request an absentee ballot by the state. Voters can also download the absentee ballot request form by visiting www.claytonelections.com.

Clayton County Public Schools has partnered with the Clayton County Government’s Clayton County Complete Count Census Committee and the U.S. Census Bureau Atlanta Regional Office to encourage all residents of Clayton County to participate in the 2020 United States Census.

According to the Census Response Rate map, (https://2020census.gov/en/response-rates.html), as of April 22, 2020, only 47.2% of Clayton County residents have responded to the invitations to participate in the census provided via U.S. Mail in March. This is the second-lowest response rate of the counties in the metro area.

As we all work to complete the 2020 Census (https://my2020census.gov), please see the press release and informational material regarding the Census!

Superintendent Proposes to Accelerate Extending Learning Beyond The Classroom Initiative

Clayton County Public Schools is pleased to announce an expansion of its Learning Beyond the Classroom Initiative. ALL students in grades 3rd through 12th will receive devices to increase academic achievement if approved by the Board of Education. The plan will also include daily use of laptops for all K-2 students with devices to use over planned digital learning days in the new school year. District leaders will also focus efforts on sharing news about internet access to families in need of wifi capabilities. More details about this initiative will be revealed during the Board of Education virtual meeting scheduled to take place on Monday, May 4, 2020, at 6:00 p.m.
